title: How to grammatically end the sentence when one uses 'right' ending a sentence in informal conversation? 'Now those were tiny wins, right?' Now those were tiny wins, right. OR Now those were tiny wins right. I'd either #1 or #2 - Quora

response.answer_text: Using right? at the end of the sentence is asking for confirmation of your statement, so a comma separating the statement part from the question is needed, as is the question mark at the end.
Look at the meanings: “Now those were tiny wins, right?” means the same as the following: Do you agree that those were tiny wins? It is a question, albeit informal, so the correct ending is #1.
